title: 12-Day Spectacular Uganda Primates and Wildlife Safari
tagline: The Complete Uganda Experience — Gorillas, Chimps, Culture & Safari
description: Uganda rewards those who give it time. This twelve-day journey is designed to do exactly that — to peel back the layers of this extraordinary country until you've seen the deepest jungle and the widest savannah, trekked gorillas and chimps, shared a meal with an ancient highland community, visited the original forest dwellers, and paddled a dugout canoe across a lake so beautiful it doesn't look real. From the zebras of Lake Mburo to the tree-climbing lions of Ishasha; from the Batwa pygmies of Kisoro to a silverback in full Bwindi glory — this is Uganda at its most spectacular. Two gorilla permits included. No corners cut. No moments missed.

itinerary.title: Arrival in Entebbe
itinerary.description: Your guide meets you at Entebbe International Airport and transfers you to a comfortable guesthouse just minutes from Lake Victoria's northern shore. Entebbe is a leafy, unhurried town that sets the tone perfectly for the adventure ahead — green, warm, alive with birdsong. Settle in, enjoy a hearty meal, and listen to your guide's briefing on the twelve days to come. Uganda already smells different: greener, richer, full of possibility.

itinerary.title: Entebbe to Lake Mburo National Park
itinerary.description: An early start carries you south-west through Kampala and out across the rolling plains of western Uganda. At the Equator you stop — everyone does — to straddle two hemispheres, watch the famous water-vortex experiment (which really does spin in opposite directions on each side), and take the obligatory photograph. By afternoon you're in Lake Mburo National Park: Uganda's smallest national park and its most charming. It's the only place in the country to see zebra, impala, and topi, and the afternoon game drive reveals the park in golden-hour light.

Equator crossing with water-vortex experiment and photos

itinerary.title: Lake Mburo Morning Walk & Transfer to Lake Bunyonyi
itinerary.description: The early morning is the best time to be in Lake Mburo — when the light is low, the air cool, and the animals still active near the water. Rise at dawn for a guided nature walk to the hyena den through the mixed acacia woodland, where waterbucks, zebras, and a dazzling variety of birds greet the day. Afterwards, a leisurely breakfast, then the drive south into the Kigezi highlands — the 'Switzerland of Africa' — climbing steadily until Lake Bunyonyi appears below you: 29 islands scattered across cobalt water at 1,800 metres above sea level, so beautiful it stops conversation.
activities: Early morning guided nature walk: hyena den, waterbucks, zebras, birds
Breakfast at the lodge
Drive south through the Kigezi highlands

itinerary.title: Free Day at Lake Bunyonyi
itinerary.description: Today belongs entirely to you — and to the lake. Lake Bunyonyi is one of very few lakes in Uganda free from hippos, crocodiles, and bilharzia, which means you can swim freely in its cool, clear water. Spend the morning paddling a dugout canoe between the islands, visiting the birdwatching spots that line the shore, or hiking the Bushara trail through local farmland and coffee gardens. In the afternoon, simply lie on the grass and watch the light change over the water. This deliberate rest day is built into the safari for good reason — you'll need the energy for what's ahead.

itinerary.title: Bakiga Cultural Homestay at Kabutungu
itinerary.description: Leave the lake behind and drive to Kabutungu — the heartland of the Bakiga people. The Bakiga are an ethnic group of the Kigezi highlands whose cultural traditions run deep: elaborate drumming and dance ceremonies, traditional farming practices, and extraordinary skill in basket weaving and pottery. Today you don't observe — you participate. Help with the morning farm work, try your hand at weaving, eat a traditional Bakiga meal prepared by your host family, and as the evening comes, let the drumbeats and dancing draw you in. This is not a curated experience — it is a genuine invitation into a living culture, and it is one of the most talked-about days of the entire safari.

itinerary.title: Drive to Kisoro — Batwa Pygmy Visit
itinerary.description: The drive from Kabale to Kisoro is one of Uganda's most spectacular: a winding mountain road through dense tea plantations and terraced hillsides, with the triple peaks of the Virunga volcanoes coming into view on the horizon. Near Kisoro, you visit the Batwa pygmy community — the original inhabitants of the Bwindi and Mgahinga forests, whose ancestors lived in these forests for thousands of years before the national parks displaced them. Their traditional forest knowledge — medicine, fire-making, hunting — is astonishing, and spending time with them is a humbling reminder of the human complexity of conservation. Tonight you sleep in the shadow of the gorilla forests.

itinerary.title: Gorilla Trekking in Bwindi Impenetrable Forest
itinerary.description: The moment you came for. After an early breakfast you gather at park headquarters, where your ranger-guides brief you on the gorilla family you'll visit and what to expect. Then you enter Bwindi — ancient, dense, alive with sound. The trek can take two hours or six; you follow the gorillas wherever they wander, and your ranger knows every inch of this forest. When you find them — and you will — the world stops. A silverback in dappled light, an infant tumbling through the undergrowth, a teenage male watching you with a gaze that feels uncomfortably intelligent. You have one hour, and no photograph will do it justice.
activities: Early breakfast and briefing at Bwindi park headquarters
2–6 hour gorilla trek through the rainforest
One full hour with a habituated gorilla family
Return trek and celebratory lunch
highlights: One unforgettable hour with a mountain gorilla family
Ancient Bwindi rainforest — UNESCO World Heritage Site
Expert ranger-guided trek

itinerary.title: Transfer to Ishasha — Tree-Climbing Lions
itinerary.description: A leisurely morning drive through the fringes of Bwindi delivers you to Ishasha — the southernmost sector of Queen Elizabeth National Park and one of Africa's most eccentric wildlife destinations. Ishasha is famous for lions that climb trees. Not occasionally — habitually. The park's giant fig trees are regularly colonised by whole prides who haul themselves up and spend the afternoon lounging in the canopy, tails dangling, watching the world below with magnificently bored expressions. Your afternoon game drive is your first opportunity to find them.

itinerary.title: Ishasha to Northern QENP — Game Drive
itinerary.description: The morning search for tree-climbing lions continues — early light is best for spotting the telltale shapes in the branches. Then you drive north through Queen Elizabeth National Park, the landscape opening from Ishasha's dense bush into wide, golden plains. By afternoon you're in the northern sector of the park for another game drive in a landscape that feels almost cinematic in its scale, with the snow-capped Rwenzori Mountains — the legendary 'Mountains of the Moon' — visible to the north on clear days.

itinerary.title: Chimpanzee Trekking — Kyambura Gorge
itinerary.description: Descend into the Kyambura Gorge — a dramatic, forest-filled chasm that cuts through the open savannah like a secret jungle. The chimpanzees here are habituated to human visitors, and your ranger-guide knows their ranging patterns well. You'll hear them before you see them: the whoops and screams of primates very much at home in their forest. Watch them swing and scramble through the canopy, their expressions alarmingly human, their energy inexhaustible. The gorge itself is a remarkable place — birdlife is superb, and black-and-white colobus monkeys often appear as an added bonus. An afternoon game drive on the plateau above rounds out the day.

itinerary.title: Kazinga Channel Boat Cruise
itinerary.description: Your final full wildlife day — and it ends on the water. An early morning game drive through QENP gives you one last chance at the big mammals: lions, elephants, leopard, giant forest hog. Then the afternoon Kazinga Channel boat cruise is two hours of pure, unhurried wildlife theatre. The channel connects Lake George and Lake Edward and is one of the densest concentrations of wildlife in Uganda: hundreds of hippos, Nile crocodiles, cape buffalo drinking at the water's edge, African fish eagles, pelicans, and more species of kingfisher than you can count. Your guide knows where the elephants wade in at dusk. This is the grand finale you came for.

itinerary.title: Return to Entebbe & Departure
itinerary.description: A final breakfast at the camp — the Rwenzori Mountains catching the morning light across the lake — and then the long, comfortable drive back to Entebbe. Your guide will make the journey memorable: stories of the bush, stops at roadside fruit stalls, perhaps a final Rolex omelette wrap from a Kampala street corner. You'll reach the airport in the late afternoon, carrying twelve days of extraordinary memories and, almost certainly, already thinking about when you can come back.

faqs.question: Why are two gorilla permits included in this safari?
faqs.answer: This itinerary includes two gorilla trekking experiences — one gorilla permit ($800) per person per trek. Having two permits gives you two separate experiences, potentially with different gorilla families on different days. It means that even if one trek is shorter, you still have a second opportunity to spend time with these extraordinary animals. Both permits are booked in advance by Penny Africa Safaris and should be secured at least 3–4 months ahead, particularly for the peak dry seasons.

faqs.question: Who are the Batwa pygmies and what is the visit like?
faqs.answer: The Batwa are the original inhabitants of the forests of southwestern Uganda — hunter-gatherers whose ancestors lived inside what are now Bwindi and Mgahinga national parks for thousands of years before they were displaced when the parks were gazetted in the 1990s. A visit to their community near Kisoro is a meaningful, complex experience: they share traditional forest skills, knowledge of medicinal plants, fire-making, and their cultural history. We approach these visits with deep respect, and a portion of the entry fee goes directly to the community.

faqs.question: Is Lake Bunyonyi really safe to swim in?
faqs.answer: Yes — Lake Bunyonyi is one of very few lakes in Uganda that is genuinely free from hippopotami, crocodiles, and bilharzia (the waterborne parasite found in most African lakes). At 1,800 metres above sea level with cold, clear water, it is a wonderful place to swim freely. The free day at Bunyonyi is deliberately built into the itinerary as a rest and recharge day after the intense early days of the safari.

faqs.question: How many wildlife species might we see on this safari?
faqs.answer: Queen Elizabeth National Park alone is home to around 100 mammal species and over 600 bird species — one of the highest bird counts of any national park in the world. Lake Mburo adds zebras, impalas, topis, and over 300 bird species. In total you should expect gorillas, chimpanzees, black-and-white colobus, red-tailed monkeys, olive baboons, lions, elephants, buffalo, hippos, crocodiles, and zebras — with leopard and giant forest hog possible.

faqs.question: What is the difference between trekking gorillas at Bwindi and chimpanzees at Kyambura?
faqs.answer: They're very different experiences. Gorilla trekking in Bwindi involves hiking through ancient, dense rainforest to find a specific habituated family — each trek is unique, unpredictable, and profoundly moving. Chimpanzee trekking at Kyambura Gorge involves descending into a dramatic forest canyon that cuts through the QENP savannah, where a habituated chimp community lives. Chimps are much louder and more acrobatic than gorillas — the energy is completely different, and the gorge landscape itself is spectacular. Both are unmissable.

faqs.question: Can this itinerary be customised?
faqs.answer: Absolutely — this 12-day itinerary is a popular base that we regularly customise. Common additions include an extra night at Lake Bunyonyi, Kibale Forest chimpanzee trekking (the best in Uganda), a Mabamba swamp shoebill boat trip, or white rhino tracking at Ziwa Sanctuary. We can also reduce the duration for shorter trips. Contact us and we'll build the perfect trip around your interests and schedule.
